channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: India Ink: Pesticide in Lunch That Killed 23 in Bihar, Forensic Report Says
item.description: A forensic science laboratory has confirmed the high presence of a pesticide in the midday meal that killed 23 children in Bihar earlier this week.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR

item.title: Pesticide Found in Meals That Killed Indian Children, Official Says
item.description: A forensic investigation found that the meals had been prepared with cooking oil that contained strong levels of a compound used as a pesticide.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Governing Party Appears Headed to Lead Japanese Parliament
item.description: Japanese voters appeared to hand a decisive victory to the Liberal Democratic Party in upper house elections, giving the party a monopoly for the first time in six years.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: King Albert Makes Way for Son Philippe
item.description: King Albert of Belgium has abdicated after a 20-year reign with his son Philippe ready to take the oath as the nation’s seventh king.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Australia Defends New Refugee Policy, Despite Riot
item.description: Following a riot in Nauru and the first arrival of a vessel under the new policy, senior officials stood firm on the choice to send to Papua New Guinea all who arrive by boat without a visa.
item.dc:creator: By MATT SIEGEL

item.title: Magnitude 6.9 Quake Strikes Off New Zealand Coast
item.description: The New Zealand capital Wellington was rattled by a strong earthquake on Sunday that broke water mains, smashed windows and downed power lines. No injuries were reported.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Hauling New Treasure Along the Silk Road
item.description: With freight trains as their caravans, manufacturers like Hewlett-Packard are reviving an ancient way to ship products made in China to markets in Western Europe.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: U.S. Intelligence Official Says Syrian War Could Last for Years
item.description: A senior American intelligence official on Saturday warned that the Syrian conflict could last “many, many months to multiple years.”
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT and MARK MAZZETTI
item.media:description: Free Syrian Army fighters prepared a homemade missile in Deir al-Zour on Saturday. The city has been one of the centers of fighting since the civil war began. In recent months, the government of President Bashar al-Assad has made gains against the rebels.

item.title: President Lifts Emergency Rule in Myanmar
item.description: The emergency decree was put into effect after Buddhist-led mobs went on a rampage in March, killing dozens of Muslims.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Car Bombs Kill Dozens in Baghdad and Nearby
item.description: Bombings and other attacks have killed more than 250 people since the start of Ramadan on July 10.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Former Motorcycle Driver, Paralyzed in Beating, Sets Off Bomb at Beijing Airport
item.description: A man in a wheelchair, the only one hurt by the bomb, was said to have ignited it to protest government inaction after he was paralyzed in a beating by security officers.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: Medical workers and policemen at Beijing International Airport on Saturday, after a man set off a homemade bomb.

item.title: Egypt to Take New Look at Syrian Ties
item.description: Egypt’s interim foreign minister sought to distance the new government’s policy on Syria from that of former President Mohamed Morsi, who helped make the country a hub for Syrian opposition groups.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and ASMAA AL ZOHAIRY

item.title: Enlisting Damascus Residents to Answer Assad’s Call
item.description: Damascus’s Old City has been largely unscathed by war, but a New Jersey man raised there is helping arm and organize militias to protect the historic district.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:credit: Andrea Bruce for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Old City of Damascus has been largely unscathed by war, but a New Jersey man raised there is helping arm and organize new militias to protect the historic district. Hussein Beydoun, top, volunteered to help defend a shrine.

item.title: 5 Convicted in 2012 Italian Cruise Wreck
item.description: An Italian court accepted plea bargains in connection with the wreck of the Costa Concordia that killed 32 people.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: For South Sudan and the U.N., a Relationship of Growing Distrust
item.description: South Sudan, which the United Nations helped midwife into existence, has become one of the most dangerous theaters of operations for the world body.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By JOSH KRON and NICHOLAS KULISH
item.media:description: South Sudanese soldiers. The country has become one of the most dangerous theaters of operations for the United Nations.

item.title: Despite Education Advances, a Host of Afghan School Woes
item.description: It is widely accepted that demand among Afghans for better schooling — and the actual opportunity to attend, particularly for girls — is at its highest point in decades.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A student at Mir Ali Ahmad Girls School in Parwan Province, Afghanistan. Most girls drop out between sixth and ninth grades.

item.title: Colombian Rebels Holding an American
item.description: The FARC said that it took a former American service member hostage last month and that it now plans to release him as a sign of good will during continuing peace talks.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: 6 Sentenced to Life in Rape of Tourist in India
item.description: A court sentenced six men to life in prison for the gang rape of a Swiss tourist last March, one of several highly publicized cases that stirred public anger over sexual assaults in India.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Five people were led by policemen after being arrested in connection with the gang rape of a female Swiss tourist in Madhya Pradesh in March.

item.title: Pope, in an Angered Brazil, to Focus on Social Justice
item.description: Pope Francis seems to see his trip, after big protests, as a way to direct attention on the gospel of social justice that he has said he wants to make the focus of his papacy.
item.dc:creator: By LARRY ROHTER
item.media:description: A man sold posters of Pope Francis on Thursday in Rocinha, a large slum of Rio de Janeiro.

item.title: G-20 Ministers Aim for More Job Growth
item.description: Officials said that the governments in the Group of 20 “are fully committed to taking decisive actions to return to a robust, job-rich growth path.”
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Finance officials on Saturday endorsed continued government spending to prime the global economy for a full recovery.

item.title: Venezuela Stops Efforts to Improve U.S. Relations
item.description: Venezuela made the announcement in reaction to comments by the Obama administration’s nominee for United Nations ambassador, who said that part of her role would be to challenge a “crackdown on civil society.”
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: Death of Watermelon Vendor Sets Off Outcry in China
item.description: An unusually loud outcry followed the vendor’s death in a squabble with urban management agents, who for many Chinese are the most visible face of the authoritarian impulses of the government.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Palestinian Prisoner Release Is Critical Hurdle in Resuming Peace Talks
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry is counting on an Israeli decision to release Palestinian prisoners as the remaining step for his promised resumption of Middle East peace talks, officials said Saturday.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Karzai Signs Second Election Law, Clearing Way for Presidential Vote Next Year
item.description: If the vote is held and a new leader replaces President Hamid Karzai, it would be the first time Afghanistan has had a peaceful transfer of power.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG

item.title: Belgium Is Also Awaiting Possible News of a New Royal
item.description: The country will install a new king Sunday, but all eyes are on a woman who claims to be the abdicating king’s illegitimate daughter.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: Workers set up seating in front of Belgium's royal palace. On Sunday, Albert II will sign a declaration of abdication and then his son, Crown Prince Philippe, will be sworn in.
